item.title: Regime Change in Cuba Appeals to Trump but Carries Risks
item.description: The Trump administration is signaling a different approach, after demanding an end to Cuba’s communist leadership.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: “Cuba does not kneel,” the country’s president, Miguel Díaz-Canel, center, told a state-run newspaper this month.

item.title: After a Speedboat Shootout in Cuba, There are More Questions Than Answers
item.description: The Cuban government’s account of a supposed armed raid into its territory was called into question after one of the men identified as being on the boat turned up in Miami.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles and Patricia Mazzei
item.media:description: Cuban coast guard ships docked at the Port of Havana on Thursday.

item.title: Netflix Backs Out of Bid for Warner Bros., Paving Way for Paramount Takeover
item.description: The move was a stunning development in the long-running corporate battle for the storied media giant.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch, Michael M. Grynbaum and Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Stella Kalinina for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paramount Pictures in Hollywood.

item.title: Hillary Clinton Denies Knowing Epstein or His Crimes in a Tense Deposition
item.description: After resisting testifying for months, the former secretary of state entered the session defiant, and grew irate after a Republican leaked a photo from inside the room.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform

item.title: Justice Department Exposed Cooperating Witnesses in Epstein Files
item.description: The disclosure is the latest example of how the urgent push to release the files led to the government publicizing information it would normally keep under wraps.
item.dc:creator: Jonah E. Bromwich and William K. Rashbaum
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Several defendants mentioned in the Epstein files conducted what are known as proffer sessions at 500 Pearl Street, the address of the federal district courthouse in Manhattan.

item.title: How a Close Associate of Epstein’s Found Career Redemption in Japan
item.description: Top Japanese officials are backing a tech and entrepreneurship initiative led by Joichi Ito, whose involvement with Jeffrey Epstein may endanger efforts to get the project off the ground.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis and Hisako Ueno

item.title: World Economic Forum Chief Resigns Over Epstein Ties
item.description: Borge Brende, a former foreign minister of Norway, had maintained contact with the convicted sex offender.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Borge Brende led the World Economic Forum, which runs an annual summit in Davos, Switzerland, for more than eight years.

item.title: Pentagon Fires Another Laser at Drone, Prompting New Air Closure
item.description: After the downing of a Customs and Border Protection drone, the F.A.A. closed the airspace above Fort Hancock, Texas.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian, Kate Kelly, Eric Schmitt and Chris Cameron
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)
item.media:description: A police officer walked with a police dog at El Paso International Airport, after the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration lifted its temporary closure of the airspace over El Paso earlier this month.

item.title: Trump Declared Victory in Minneapolis. But What Did He Accomplish?
item.description: The Trump administration came under fire for an operation that turned lethal and politically toxic. But the show of force may also have had a bigger purpose: to serve as a warning.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Ernesto Londoño
item.media:description: Federal agents confronting protesters in Minneapolis last month. Sheriffs and public officials across the state say little, if anything, has changed about their immigration enforcement policies since the federal operation.

item.title: Federal Judge Accuses Trump Administration of Repeatedly Disobeying Orders
item.description: The federal judge identified 210 orders issued in 143 cases in Minnesota in which he said Immigration and Customs Enforcement officials had not complied with court orders.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith, Ernesto Londoño and Mattathias Schwartz
item.media:credit: U.S. District Court of Minnesota, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Judge Patrick Schiltz was nominated to the bench by President George W. Bush.

item.title: Trump Ally Expands Inquiry of Former Officials Who Investigated the President
item.description: The office of a prosecutor based in Miami has issued new subpoenas in a wide-ranging inquiry aimed at President Trump’s perceived foes.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some of President Trump’s allies have hoped that Jason A. Reding Quiñones, the U.S. attorney for the District of Southern Florida, would develop a “grand conspiracy” inquiry.

item.title: What Your DNA Reveals About the Sex Life of Neanderthals
item.description: Most people alive today carry fragments of Neanderthal DNA in their genome. Now scientists are gaining a more intimate understanding of the ancient encounters that put it there.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:description: An artist’s rendering of a human skull, at left, and a Neanderthal skull. Most people alive today carry a bit of Neanderthal DNA in their genome, the result of interbreeding tens of thousands of years ago.

item.title: Columbia Student Is Released From ICE After Mamdani-Trump Meeting
item.description: Federal officials had misrepresented themselves to gain access, according to the university. Mayor Zohran Mamdani said President Trump had told him the student would be let go.
item.dc:creator: Sharon Otterman
item.media:credit: CS Muncy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hundreds of protesters gathered outside Columbia on Thursday to protest the detention of a student, Elmina Aghayeva, by federal authorities.

item.title: Mamdani Meets Again With Trump, Emerging With Two Unexpected Victories
item.description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani said he and President Trump discussed building housing in New York City, and he appeared to secure the release of a Columbia student detained by ICE on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Dana Rubinstein, Nicholas Fandos, Sally Goldenberg and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani of New York and President Trump held an unannounced meeting at the White House on Thursday, each accompanied by his chief of staff.

item.title: Mamdani’s Gift for Trump: A Front Page Celebrating the President
item.description: What do you bring the president when you visit the White House? Mayor Zohran Mamdani made a choice that seemed to please Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:credit: NY Daily News Archive, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The famous New York Daily News front page from Oct. 30, 1975, after President Gerald Ford refused to bail out New York City, which was facing bankruptcy.

item.title: Pakistan Strikes Afghanistan in ‘Open War’ Against Taliban Regime
item.description: The airstrikes came hours after Afghan troops had attacked Pakistani border positions and follow months of worsening relations between the neighboring countries.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Safiullah Padshah
item.media:description: The Afghan capital, Kabul. Pakistan bombed major cities in Afghanistan including Kabul on Friday.

item.title: Iranians Cite Progress in Talks, but a Marathon Session Produces No Deal
item.description: Representatives of the countries were in Geneva this week to discuss the fate of Iran’s nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: The U.S. special envoy Steve Witkoff, who, with Jared Kushner, Mr. Trump’s son-in-law, is negotiating with Iran’s foreign minister Abbas Araghchi.

item.title: Fact-check: In Trump’s Case for an Attack on Iran, False or Unproven Claims
item.description: Key elements of the Trump administration’s arguments this week for another military campaign against Iran do not hold up.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti, Edward Wong, David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: People walked past a missile system and banners of Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran’s supreme leader, in Tehran last year.

item.title: Anthropic Says It Cannot ‘Accede’ to Pentagon in Talks Over A.I.
item.description: Anthropic said it was standing firm on not having its A.I. used in certain scenarios by the Pentagon, which has imposed a Friday deadline on the company to give unfettered access to its technology.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Sheera Frenkel
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: “We cannot in good conscience accede to their request,” Dario Amodei, chief executive of Anthropic, said in a statement.

item.title: Google Workers Seek ‘Red Lines’ on Military A.I., Echoing Anthropic
item.description: More than 100 Google A.I. employees sent a letter to Jeff Dean, a chief scientist, opposing Gemini’s use for U.S. surveillance and some autonomous weapons.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:description: Jeff Dean, the chief scientist of Google DeepMind, Google’s artificial intelligence division, at a company event in 2018.

item.title: After F.B.I. Raid, Los Angeles School Board Discusses Superintendent’s Future
item.description: Board members held an emergency meeting a day after agents raided the home and office of Alberto Carvalho, the Los Angeles Unified School District superintendent. They did not reach a resolution and agreed to reconvene Friday.
item.dc:creator: Dana Goldstein and Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Los Angeles Unified school board members met Thursday afternoon in an emergency closed session a day after the F.B.I. raid of Alberto Carvalho’s home.

item.title: Why Are So Many Teen Girls Still Tearing Their A.C.L.s?
item.description: For years, ligament tears have been a crisis among young athletes — even though a few simple exercises can prevent them.
item.dc:creator: Craig Welch
item.media:credit: Dru Donovan for The New York Times
item.media:description: [PHOTO ONLY:] The LA Breakers U13 soccer team who regularly does the “FIFA 11+,” a series of exercises designed to prevent ACL tears and other injuries.

item.title: Jesse Jackson Memorials Begin in Chicago
item.description: Mourners lined up outside Rainbow PUSH, the organization Mr. Jackson founded decades ago. He died last week at 84.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman and Jamie Kelter Davis
item.media:description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, a prominent civil rights leader and the founder of the Rainbow PUSH Coalition, died on Feb. 17.

item.title: Germany’s Oil and Gas Output Is Dwindling as Prices Rise
item.description: Natural gas production in Germany has fallen about 80 percent in the past two decades even as the country seeks to replace flows from Russia.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed and Maximilian Mann
item.media:description: The Gas Nord production facility of Harbour Energy Germany in Langwedel-Holtebüttel.

item.title: Bird Losses Are Accelerating, New Study Finds
item.description: Scientists studying data collected over more than three decades found accelerating losses. Their research offers clues about the causes.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.media:description: The steepest losses in the study, from 1987 to 2021, were seen in Florida, Texas, Louisiana and Arizona.

item.title: ‘We’re Going to the Moon and Mars’
item.description: The new head of NASA predicts a manned mission to Mars in 10 years.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat and Victoria Chamberlin

item.title: Trump’s Shields Are Down
item.description: Personnel once meant policy; now it means flattery.
item.dc:creator: Carlos Lozada
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by The New York Times; source photographs by Associated Press, Reuters and Getty Images

item.title: Green Party Defeats Labour in U.K. Special Election, in Blow to Starmer
item.description: The result marks the first time the Greens have won a British parliamentary by-election and signals the frustration of left-leaning voters with Prime Minister Keir Starmer.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: Hannah Spencer, who won a historic victory for the Green Party on Thursday, outside a polling station in the Gorton and Denton district outside Manchester.

item.title: Supreme Court Lawyer Who Moonlighted in High-Stakes Poker Is Convicted of Tax Fraud
item.description: The lawyer Thomas C. Goldstein, who co-founded the SCOTUSblog website, hid millions in gambling income from the government, federal prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:description: Thomas Goldstein represented Epic Games, makers of the popular Fortnite video game, in an antitrust case brought against Apple in the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, in 2022.

item.title: N.Y. Man With China Ties Charged With Marijuana Trafficking in Oklahoma
item.description: Sin Tung Chan was a member of a prominent hometown association in the city, one of hundreds of social clubs that often maintain close ties with the Chinese government.
item.dc:creator: Jay Root, Michael Forsythe and Bianca Pallaro
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Purple Ray L.L.C., one of two large marijuana farms owned by Sin Tung Chan in rural Oklahoma, was raided on Wednesday.
